review:
Un juego que no esta mal y sin grandes pretensiones. 

No espereis el juego de vuestra vida y recomiendo cogerlo en oferta solo. No echaria en falta el juego si no lo tuviera pero tampoco es un juego que me arrepienta de tener o jugar. simplemente cumple es entretenido y para ratos muertos. Pero puede ser mas que suficiente para esos momentos y con un toque diferente y original.

author: {'steamid': '76561198429074257', 'num_games_owned': 1455, 'num_reviews': 1353, 'playtime_forever': 208, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 208, 'last_played': 1645265478}
review:
Pretty simple and partly easy arcade game.
By controlling a revived electric spark, you need to help the city restore electricity in several areas. Turn on the lights, start the generators and air conditioners to complete the levels with three stars.
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2758072895
You are also waiting for several "bosses" and a strange - but no less cute - the end of the game.

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list][*]+ Good graphics
[*]+ Nice soundtrack
[*]+ Simple controls
[*]+ Achievements
[*]+ Trading cards for sale[/list]

[b]Minuses:[/b]
[list][*]- On levels with a chase, the firefly has unresponsive controls.
[*]- Many bugs in which the hero can move through the air without using wires
https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2758073120
[*]- Physics "jumping" from the wires in the foreground - to the background. Works quite clumsily.[/list]

[b]Result[/b]:
Pretty simple game, straight out of 2016. Good for both kids and adults.
I recommend the game for purchase - but at a discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054690449', 'num_games_owned': 1377, 'num_reviews': 182, 'playtime_forever': 315, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 315, 'last_played': 1622182434}
review:
This game isn't very engaging and many areas are downright frustrating.  The foreground/background transitions alongside poor camera centering equate to a lot of blind jumps and difficulty telling where to go.  In addition, the autorunner sequences don't really give you enough warning or time to react given the controls.  Then there's that level with the rising current; the timing of the platforms was way off from a first cycle possibility and the rising shock doesn't stop during cutscenes.

Then there's that weird glitch where you float on nothing...

Turn away from this one, especially for a $15 price tag.

author: {'steamid': '76561198168731262', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 1218, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1133, 'last_played': 1614739646}
review: It's adorable and soothing, and just the right amount of challenging. You might have to replay levels several times, but it's only rarely infuriating- the controls are simple, the soundtrack's sweet, if a bit repetitive, and the graphics are cute. All in all, 8/10, definitely worth the price.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025675343', 'num_games_owned': 384, 'num_reviews': 32, 'playtime_forever': 503, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 308, 'last_played': 1612589016}
review:
I really, really wanted to like this game. I really did. The art style's is adorable, the little spark you play as is just so cute, and I love that you move between the foreground and background layers in game. It was even made as a means of bringing awareness to Earth Hour, when everyone is supposed to turn off electronics for an hour to conserve energy or whatever. Everything about this game I should like is there. But there's a big reason I personally didn't enjoy this and I'll get into that after I explain what the game is about and like.

TurnOn is a side-scrolling puzzle platformer where you play as an alien entity made solely of electricity that can only move through electrical currents. You must use your innate electrical charge to turn on items to solve puzzles, collect energy, and try to otherwise help Electro City deal with a sudden blackout. Some levels are chase or fast paced platforming segments instead, and if you've ever played any of the minecart stages in Rare's Donkey Kong Country games, they feel a lot like that in a way mixed with a rhythm-based system. It's a nice idea, but maybe a bit much for this sort of game. Feels slightly tacked on but I get what they were going for - electricity moving to new places through high voltage wires, clever and fun.

The graphics are simple, but cute - I love how the little spark has its eyes move and squish as it moves along the wires, and I love the papery aesthetic done in 2.5D. It's really very cute and friendly. The music is also quite nice, if a bit generic in some spots and a bit unfitting in others. It's pretty clear that the creators just picked songs they thought fit, but it's a shame so many of them sound like Youtube Creator Studio stock music when it has a nice mix of styles otherwise. I feel that it should have stuck to either a gentle orchestral, jazz. or electroswing type feel, but instead it runs through many disparate styles and they just don't all work together even if they're all pleasant to listen to.

Now for what I didn't like. First off, the controls. WASD/Arrows is perfect for this particular game because you only move in four directions anyway (up is also jump which makes sense here), but I often felt especially on faster paced or timed sections that jumping was much, much more difficult than it needed to be. It somehow was both too loose and too precise IMHO. For example, when trying to jump up I felt like I should have a bit more height as the spark's hitbox doesn't quite reach enough to cling to the next wire on some jumps. I'm not a physicist or electrician, but come on, you're sentient electricity - I know IRL that electricity can only easily jump smallish gaps, but electricity has a charge, and charges attract opposite charges, so shouldn't it be a lot easier to cling to charged items like wires? I know this is a game, but guys... really? It's frustrating to have a wire just out of reach, especially when the spark can make some jumps that would reasonably be several feet away, yet can't seem to jump up and grab a wire that is not even a foot above its ball-lightning body.

Second, the foreground and background do not always make clear what can and cannot be jumped to. I often found myself falling off wires because I thought I could make a jump to another FG or BG object, but turns out no, you can't do that. This seems to happen without any real rhyme or reason, making some puzzles more difficult than they needed to be. Under this point I'll mention an issue I had with the platforming in general: some parts are so pixel perfect you have to be at the absolute tippy top or you won't make it, and some moving platform puzzles are even harder than they should be because trying to control the jump midair feels loose. Especially when falling down, I found controlling the arc of the jump difficult and a little too floaty, which made some types of platforming difficult. Furthermore, when landing, the spark tends to slide forward, making it difficult to dodge things coming at you or not fall off the platform. It was clearly supposed to feel good to go fast, but I can't go fast when I'm worried about how the next jump is going to land and IF it's gonna land in some cases. Also, this is a bit nitpicky, but I have never met a single gamer that truly enjoyed a moving-wall segment. Call me nuts here, but I'm pretty sure that nobody actually likes these. I get that the final level was a throwback to older Nintendo platformers with the tower, but come on. Make the platforming tighter so we can move quicker, or at least give us a break. There's no reason for the checkpoint to give you mere seconds to start moving when the wall of death is an instant kill, and there's never, NEVER any reason for an instant kill wall to move in a cutscene, that's just cruel for the sake of cruel. I picked up this game to relax, not yell at my screen because I can't make it to the next platform in time because the insta kill wall is right on my butt.

Third, the glitches. So many, so often. None really game breaking, but still. Several times I ended up floating midair for no reason, but still able to move. Sometimes the music breaks on some of the rhythm-minecart type segments, and sometimes it will reset your electricity counter or start you back at the wrong checkpoint during them. Button inputs occasionally did not work when I clearly pressed them. Sometimes, collectibles will not be collected, even if you are sitting right on top of them. A few times, I was completely stuck on the scenery bouncing or unable to move, but it got better. Once, at the start of a level, I randomly couldn't move at all and had to restart the level over. I'd think this must be to do with the spark's hitbox possibly being too small, same as with some platforming issues, but still. Glitches, they are there. I know this was more of a game jam type game, but you'd think there would be some more polish before you put it on Steam, that's all...

All things considered, I'm not so sure that I can recommend paying full price for this. TurnOn has plenty to like, but I did not have that great a time with it personally. Maybe it's that it's too short for $15 - it took me all of five hours to beat it, most of which was spent being frustrated at having to do the same exact rhythm-based minecart style levels twenty times just to get an inch further along the wires. Maybe it's because the platforming was too artificially hard, or the puzzles too easy, IDK. I wanna like it so bad, I wanna recommend it, but I can't. I'd recommend if you want a better platformer with tighter controls, pick up Hollow Knight or Sundered; if you want a better puzzle platformer, pick up Incredipede or Mutant Blobs Attack. If you really do want this game, wait until it's on sale for about $10 or less.

review:
[b][i]Arrependido de nÃ£o ter jogado antes, estava na biblioteca por 2 anos, manias de um acumulador. Apesar de nÃ£o ter este marcador, TurnOn se trata de mais um indie de plataforma, do subgÃªnero "relaxante" sem grandes desafios.[/i][/b]

[b]Depois que seu experimento falha, um cientista causa um apagÃ£o em toda a cidade. VocÃª o ajuda normalizar a situaÃ§Ã£o, controlando uma faÃ­sca de eletricidade muito cute.

A mecÃ¢nica Ã© gostosa, navegue por fios de postes e luzes. Os cenÃ¡rios mesclam elementos 3D com 2D de uma maneira satisfatÃ³ria, com fases bem variadas, muitos detalhes e animaÃ§Ãµes. Pensei que se tornaria repetitivo, mas a dinÃ¢mica dos puzzles consegue ser alternativa, sem cair na mesmice.

GrÃ¡fico singelo, mas bem detalhado e com uma paleta de cores bonita e "viva". Destaque tambÃ©m para a trilha sonora, bem diversificada e relaxante.[/b]

[i][b]3 Reais em sale, conquistas, cartas. SÃ³ vai.[/b][/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198075673573', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 272, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1584481678}
review:
I rate the platformer adventure game TurnOn 3.5/5. Pretty good, especially considering how this game had a very small development team (something like 4 people only).

EDIT: (THIS GAME WAS MADE BY RUSSIANS, THEREFORE I CAN IN GOOD CONSCIENCE NO LONGER RECOMMEND THIS GAME DUE TO THE RUSSIAN INVASION OF UKRAINE).


TurnOn is a platform game wherein you control a cute little electrical alien orb which jumps from powerline to powerline turning on various electrical appliances (usually lights and generators) to bring power back to a city which has gone dark due (I guess) to an electromagnetic pulse from a passing asteroid (I guess the same asteroid that brought you to the planet to begin with). Or perhaps you were created or otherwise drawn to the surface by some weird scientist guy. 

This game, which features no real dialog, is very light on explanation concerning exactly what is going on and why. The cut-scenes leave a lot of room for interpretation also. It is fun to jump around on powerlines and turn lights on as you go but there are several segments here and there (which act like boss levels of a sort) which can be frustrating and have a much higher difficulty than the rest of the game.

+Somewhat innovative and strange platform gameplay, forcing a two-dimensional control scheme into a quasi-three dimensional environment (sometimes you can jump to a distant powerline by simply jumping up or down from the line you are at, even if it is in the background or foreground). Iâ€™m really not sure how to describe it. Merely jumping up or down can, if there is a place to jump to, cause you to jump either into the foreground or into the distance.

+Your character really is amazingly adorable despite the fact that it is essentially a bolt of electricity with a face.

+Nice, artistic artistry and colorful lighting effects.

+This game is not necessarily simply a childrenâ€™s game. Despite TurnOnâ€™s generally high level of cuteness, there is a lot of urban decay depicted in this game including lots of empty beer bottles laying around, destroyed cars and some ghetto style street parties here and there. Poverty and some of its effects are prominently depicted along with some of the crime that same poverty creates. There is some social commentary hinted at in the inner city scenes this game shows you. This game takes place in a city and it does not shy away from how the city can be an ugly place to be forced to live in when you donâ€™t have money and how that state of affairs can be even worse if thereâ€™s no electricity or other services.

+/-Controls are very responsive but I often wished that my character could jump just a little bit higher. Responds well with a keyboard but itâ€™s best to be very proficient with a keyboard if you play this game on one like I did. A controller is NOT absolutely necessary however. 

+/-OK sound though the constant electrical zapping sounds could get irritating over time. The music is mostly mediocre but can be fairly good in places, especially during the nice ending level.

-Extremely uneven difficulty. Most levels are very easy but some levels are crazy hard and some of these happen fairly early in the game (like the one where you have to defeat the weird malfunctioning flying drone and the ones where you are forced to race along on long-distance power lines at breakneck speed) These frustrating areas sort of act as boss levels between the far better designed normal areas where you just have to solve some simple puzzles and light stuff up as you make your way from point A to point B. TurnOn can become fairly challenging and frustrating very quickly with little warning. New gameplay elements occasionally come into play with no introduction or explanation of those elements whatsoever. You simply have to adapt as you go along. To decrease frustration itâ€™s probably best to play this game in short bursts rather than for hours on end.

-No character upgrades in this game. The abilities your character has at the start of the game are the same abilities your character has at the gameâ€™s end.

-Most menus are self-explanatory and simple but the status display which appears at the top left of the screen as you actually play is a bit strange and seems mostly irrelevant.

-Fairly short game which took me only 4 hours to adequately complete. Early levels will spam you with steam achievements.

-No good explanation as to why the majority of the cityâ€™s power grid is ultimately controlled by this one generator on top of the cityâ€™s tallest building. It felt as though more levels were planned but were never made.

-Highly linear game with no alternate endings or choices to make. No way to be an A-hole and turn everyoneâ€™s lights off instead. No replay value as a result.

-TurnOn sounds like it should be some sort of a hentai sex game but it isnâ€™t.

TurnOn c'est l'histoire d'une petite boule d'Ã©lectricitÃ© qui doit ramener le courant partout dans une ville, voilÃ  pour le speech. Vous devrez passer simplement sur des ampoules et autres gÃ©nÃ©rateurs tout en crapahutant d'une ligne Ã©lectrique Ã  l'autre pour que la lumiÃ¨re soit Ã  nouveau. Rien de compliquÃ© en soi.
Le jeu compte une trentaine de niveau avec parfois des niveaux de "course-poursuite" assez frustrants, je veux dire par-lÃ  qu'on passe d'un super jeu de "plate-formes" limite super zen, oÃ¹ l'on prends grand plaisir Ã  diriger notre petite boule Ã©lectrique Ã  du presque "die and retry" ! AprÃ¨s ces niveaux lÃ  ne sont heureusement pas nombreux (4 ou ( il me semble) et si vous ne cherchez pas Ã  avoir les 3 Ã©toiles de fin de niveau vous les passerez quand mÃªme assez facilement aprÃ¨s quelques essais, que cela ne vous freine pas si vous hÃ©sitez Ã  acheter le jeu.
Je vous parlais du nombre de niveau, on pourrait croire qu'il y en a beaucoup mais ils ne sont pas trÃ¨s long et, une fois encore, si vous ne cherchez pas les 3 Ã©toiles vous arriverez trÃ¨s vite Ã  bout du titre. Pour les chasseurs de succÃ¨s le jeu sera juste long comme il faut (comptez entre 5-7 heures je pense) pour le 100%.
A noter que les musiques collent trÃ¨s bien, assez calme dans les phases plate-formes et un peu plus stressantes dans les phases dÃ©filantes.
En tout cas j'ai passÃ© un agrÃ©able moment sur ce titre que je ne connaissais pas, merci la mise en avant des titres en soldes de Steam.

Les - :

author: {'steamid': '76561198030617999', 'num_games_owned': 663, 'num_reviews': 86, 'playtime_forever': 336, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 272, 'last_played': 1587276565}
review: A cute little platformer about playing a ball of electricity navigating along power lines. The shifts in perspective from foreground to background are interesting and the use of set-pieces make each level feel unique. No section is outright frustrating but the game does increase in difficulty with only the last boss feeling a tad on the cheap side.

author: {'steamid': '76561198010492777', 'num_games_owned': 373, 'num_reviews': 81, 'playtime_forever': 143, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 143, 'last_played': 1545943969}
review:
Irritating little puzzle-platformer. Imagine if Limbo was obtuse, had escort missions and very, very poorly telegraphed geography. You're a little electric ball. You live on powerlines. OK, fine. DID YOU KNOW? You can effortlessly roll from one blue line to another, via the black telephone pole arms? But you can't move on other black objects. Traversal is effortless, except when the tools you are given to climb or descend are just out of reach, for no real reason - it's a casual game, not a precision platformer.

The sound effects are unbelievably painful - not the music or the orb, they're fine. But the people - quivering scientists, shrieking babies (really) and other townsfolk all have exactly 1 sound each, play it constantly, and you can't turn it off or you miss important sound cues.

I want to like this game - casual puzzle-platformers are extremely my jam - but it's just annoying enough in just enough ways to be a pass instead of a recommend from me. And I paid $1.50. At $15, I'd be incredibly salty.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127623102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 14, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1542947370}
review: There's just not that much to say about the game. The music is okay, the graphics aren't impressive, and the gameplay is pretty boring. There's no fatal flaw in the game, but there's nothing to keep me playing it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072153080', 'num_games_owned': 175, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 41, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 41, 'last_played': 1542998328}
review:
This game is perfect to take it easy after a long day of work/school/gamming hard/ pretty much anything... It is a very relaxing game, nice music, easy controls, funny-cute story, good graphics/art/animations, the sounds of some characters/objects made me smile a lot!! The achievements are not that hard to get... This game has all!! You might die/fail, so what? Nothing bad happens. The little things this game has, make it really good :) 
Just buy it!! It is worth the shot. You do not want to spend the money, then buy it on sale like I did (for about 2 Euros or so) but still, you will not regret it ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198070205606', 'num_games_owned': 4178, 'num_reviews': 145, 'playtime_forever': 78, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 78, 'last_played': 1540091088}
review:
You have exploratory collecting levels, which are pretty fun. 
Then you have auto scrolling levels which seem just so horribly made and out of place.  The timing for the jumps is bizarre resulting in constant deaths, poor checkpoint system, far too many dangers which can result in the reset of the whole level.   These levels absolutely ruin the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034831097', 'num_games_owned': 1011, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 675, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 675, 'last_played': 1536549079}
review:
TurnOn is an unusual game. It is very much its own thing and players should keep that in mind before getting started. In a loose sense, it is a platformer, but all the action takes place between power lines, and touching the ground forces you back to the most recent checkpoint. As a spark of energy, you go around the levels turning lights on and powering machinery in order to restore order to a city that has been plunged into darkness, and is suffering from all sorts of problems, from failed marriage proposals to all out riots and vandalism.

All of this takes place on a particularly charming world with a cartoon style to it, and it's quite enjoyable to watch the consequences of your actions unfolding as you help citizens go about their lives. Sounds good? Well, it is, only... perpective works quite strangely in this game. Your character has a set size that doesn't change no matter how deep into the environment you are. In this sense, to jump to a power line that is behind you, the character does not really change planes, but rather when you jump up, it gets snapped by the line farther behind and you are able to interact with it.

Now, sometimes the camera follows you in an appropriate manner, but at others it doesn't. It's kind of convoluted, but it works just fine. You shouldn't be discouraged to play it because of this, but like I said, do understand how quirky it is before getting into the game. I saw some complaints on reviews about there being many blind jumps, but I never really felt like there were more than a few of those, and I completed the game 100%, so take that with a grain of salt. A more valid complaint is about the autoscrolling levels, which are not that good, but they are very playable if you are not aiming to collect evevything; if you are... yeah, they kind of suck. Just get over it.

Overall, the experience is so unique that I cannot help but recommend it. There is not exactly anything else like it out there, so on orginality alone it is worth giving a spin.

review:

Die Steuerung ist einfach, WASD fÃ¼r alle Richtungen!
Grafik ist gut gelungen, vor allem die Lichteffekte hamonisieren gut.

Herausforderung bieten die vielen Errungenschaften (82) welche von Secrets finden, bis zum"perfekten" AbschlieÃŸen der Levels oder bestimmten Beleuchtugnen, welche man anwerfen muss, reicht.

Abwechslung bieten dabei der ein oder andere "Bosskampf" oder Level, bei dem man Ã¼ber das groÃŸe Stromnetz wie auf Schienen fÃ¤hrt und sich nach oben oder unten bewegen muss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198118741054', 'num_games_owned': 1297, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1704854483}
review:
Hmmmmmmm......

I like this game. I really do. It has charm out the yinny, an interesting concept, and alright level design. The graphics are nothing to write home about, but graphics are never my first concern. I like that the devs tried their best to not make this just a pretty but boring ol' collectathon.

So it's better than Poncho.  It has that going for it.

But what stops me from recommending this game is what stops me from recommending any game: lack of polish and lack of understanding the audience. 

The collectathon levels and the running levels do not mesh well for me. I like a challenge, but I would not have expected one from this game considering the first few levels are relaxed, enemy-less, Rube Goldberg-infused collectathons (which, if I have not made it clear already, I find to be charming and fun). But there it is; the first few levels are chill and great, but then the running levels kick in. While they aren't impassibly difficult, they, dare I say, ruin the momentum. They stick out and not in a pleasing way. Unless you enjoy being throttled about, they darn near ruin the experience. And they are fairly constant. 

Also, while I again praise the non-running level design and the Rube Goldberg-inspired themes, It's clear that not quite enough testing went into even the middle levels. Jumps that would have worked in previous levels clearly do not in later ones, and that is quite a shame; I want to see later levels, but I won't live in frustration. Maybe I'm just not that dedicated a gamer, but there are loads of other games to play that have good concept and design and actually WORK.

I don't expect miracles; I expect love. There was much apparent love put into this game, but, like a child that peaked at a middle school spelling bee, clearly disappointment set in early and didn't let go.

author: {'steamid': '76561198157201361', 'num_games_owned': 889, 'num_reviews': 795, 'playtime_forever': 151, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 151, 'last_played': 1519196275}
review:
the game was ok

once it glitched and my charactor went invisable
for the most part it does a good job of catching onto ropes except when transitioning from close and far away ropes then it only does an okayish job
sometimes the place you need to jump to is out of the screen so you need to faith jump
the main collectables do nothing but yay for you points

some of the music was good and at the same time some of the music while good felt like it didn't belong in the game

author: {'steamid': '76561198045630846', 'num_games_owned': 1476, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 758, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 751, 'last_played': 1515802300}
review:
Enjoyable leisurely adventure, with nice fluid controls.

 There are many stages and most of them adhere to the leisurely style, but there are four (IIRC) stages (Suburbs, Mad Tram, Get out of here, and  Lifts) that are rapid stages under pressure. The first three are like speedrunner levels, while the last is made hectic by having a "wall of death" following you, forcing you to make your maneuvers quickly.

 Some people feel these levels are out of place in the game and wish they were removed. If you're just looking to get through the speedrunner levels to continue on with the game, just [spoiler]ignore the collectible blue sparks (and green bolts unless you need one), and concentrate on staying on a live wire and avoiding the red bolts.[/spoiler]. If you're trying to get the achievement for these levels, [spoiler]take full advantage of the fact you're not penalized for falling off the wires. Jump off intentionally to redo an area where you missed some sparks. Jump off before the half way check point to keep doing the first half, and off before the finish to keep doing the 2nd half. Only the ones you missed are there on redo runs[/spoiler]

7/10

review: I am so much in love with this game. It has a calm and relax gameplay and a great soundtrack!! We have a cute alien who is called Turnon and he helps us to bring the electricity back. It is not challenging at all and has positive vibes. If you are looking for a light in your life then playing this game is a good choice.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019576097', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 322, 'playtime_forever': 210, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 210, 'last_played': 1509415151}
review:
Once I started to play, the first thing on my mind was to refund this. But after 3 or 4 levels I just could not stop playing. The history isn't great, gameplay is so so and the game is very easy and short. But it was so relaxing... the piano music was amazing, and fit the game atmosphere. It was amazing to play just to enjoy the music and solve the little puzzle so make people lives easier in this cartoonish world.

Perfect to play between major games or kill 3/4 hours without think too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198076665762', 'num_games_owned': 1343, 'num_reviews': 123, 'playtime_forever': 251, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 251, 'last_played': 1502304730}
review:
Unique platformer with cute graphics. You take role of alien electric wisp trying to help with electricity problems on Earth.

PROS:
- cute quirky 3D graphics
- good level design with some tricky places, but all is solvable
- pleasant music
- original idea
- diversity of locations

MEH:
- some levels are somewhat repetitive - there is material for 25 levels and they made 32 levels
- sometimes the levels are too easy
- the only thing you control is movement (up, down, left, right), there are no action buttons whatsoever

CONS:
- the "cut scene" graphics are 2D drawings which are somewhat ugly

The game was fun, but it's rather casual.

My rating:
GAMEPLAY 7/10
GRAPHICS 8/10
AUDIO 7/10
STORY 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198001478346', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1500799468}
review:
A cute, rather unique puzzle platformer. The game would be absolutely great, if not for the occasional runner levels, which fall flat for several reasons.

For one thing, the runner sections don't fit the pace of the rest of the game, which encourages exploration and moving back and forth. Add to this frustratingly placed and occasionally glitchy savepoints, the very precise movements and foresight required for good scores, and the occasional buggy invisible platform, and the runner levels bring a very annoying difficulty spike at the end of each section.

In general, the game is good, just be prepared for the occasional period of frustration.

author: {'steamid': '76561198402217102', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 113, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1500288375}
review:
When you play this game all you do is run around as an electric ball and you bring light back to the city. some levels are tricky but they are solvable . i picked this game up during the summer sale for 2 dollars thinking i can expect anything , i told myself that whether the game is good or bad it doesn't matter i bought it as something i can play and finish quickly though i haven't personally finished all the levels yet but i've at least gone halfway through them.

so you could get this game if you want to try a game out and finish it in 3 hours. but if you like games that last very long this isn't the one.

author: {'steamid': '76561198021613310', 'num_games_owned': 1076, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 314, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 314, 'last_played': 1499284508}

author: {'steamid': '76561198030788488', 'num_games_owned': 747, 'num_reviews': 129, 'playtime_forever': 606, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 606, 'last_played': 1498716015}
review:
[h1]TurnOn[/h1]
...is a puzzle platformer. As a little alien who crash-lands on Earth causing a blackout, you must run on the power lines to restore electricity to Electro City, helping people along the way.

[h1]âš™ [u]Game Description & Mechanics[/u] âš™[/h1]
You go from one neighborhood to another, travelling on electrical wires and other conductive surfaces, and jumping from one to the other. You supply power to lights, generators and other electrical equipment by touching them. As you seek them out throughout each level, you also collect sparks of lightning bolts along the way.

There are also musical segments, where you travel on high-tension wires at high speed, jumping from one wire to another to avoid obstacles and pits, using the music and following its beat to time your jumps and drops.

Falling off wires will throw you back to your last save points to continue where you left off, while red sparks will kill you after a few hits. In some levels, red sparks corrupted some objects that will chase you around.

[h1]â˜º [u]What I enjoyed[/u] â˜º[/h1]
While the platforming is simple enough, and patience will be all you need to find every spark and secret passages before moving to the following levels, the musical segments are much harder, at least if you care about getting a 3-lamp score at each level.

A game probably built with a younger audience in mind, it is very colorful, almost whimsical, it's unlikely that you'll mind the low resolutions and very simple animations. Each level has a basic but implied story, from lighting the path home of a little girl, you helping to lovers meet halfway, or assisting the cops calm down a riot. The gorgeous sundown and charming music will appease to many.

[h1]â˜¹ [u]What bothered me[/u] â˜¹[/h1]
Gameplay is tied, no matter how zoomed in or out the camera is. This means that jumping about an inch high "on screen" sometimes results in multiple yards leaps to a line in the foreground or background because the current camera angle shows it an inch away. This is a very unreliable, very inconsistent mechanic for a sidescrolling platformer.

The game is definitely way too easy at times, allowing unlimited retries. It's pretty easy to find all hidden sparks, so you probably won't be replaying it again to get a better score. But then come the music segments with a huge difficulty spike to the 3-lamp score, which means you might be playing over and over the same level until you get frustrated, or memorize the entire level.

[h1][b]My Verdict[/b]: â˜…â˜…â˜…â˜†â˜† - [i]"It's up to you."[/i][/h1]

This game has its charm, done by a tiny development team. While I wouldn't recommend it to hardcore gamers, [i]TurnOn[/i] is a nice little game for children or casual gamers, the only audience I will actually suggest this to.

â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”â€”
[i][b]This was just my opinion.[/b]

If you found this review helpful, please consider giving it a thumbs up, and feel free to check out more of my (purely opinionated) [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/CJsOpinions/]reviews[/url].[/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198043938050', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 52, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1498516893}
review: nice casual game  to play if you dont want something too challenging and just want to relax. I like the art style and the music is nice. My only real complaint about the game, even though its a pretty small one more of a pet peeve really. The world is rendered as a sidescroller where you move between the foreground and background to give you a sense of 3d depth. My only issue with that is your character does not change size to keep that illusion going, I.E. shrinking to portray moving further away or getting larger to move closer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198058695291', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 120, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1494945912}
review:
At first glance I wasn't sure what to make of this game. You go from place to place in this light platformer, well turning on ... lights. It sounds a bit strange at first as you're an alien ball of electricity from what I can guess trying to find your way back home. What ensues is a grand adventure through the city witnessing the chaos that happens to the mundane when the lights go out. Every few levels tells a bit of story about what you have to do and who you're helping but story elements while touching at points are very light and non-consequential to gameplay. 

Gameplay itself is a mixture of casual platformer and runner type missions. Each self contained without overall impact on each other. Now I might be a bit of a sucker for the simple stuff but I found myself genuinely enjoying my time spent in this game. There is no hardcore challenge to be had. The visuals and music brings it all together to make the experience a solid, well done and not boring. This is something I'd play if I wanted a little fun but didn't want the monotony or hardcore challenge that came with other games of the genre.

The music in this game is beautiful, and is necessary considering there's no dialogue or text moving along the story but when I'm scaling the heights of a building and the piano concerto starts to pick up I understand the urgency and pressure behind my ascent. Or during the slightly more urgent runner levels the uptempo beat that gives you the sense of urgency. In all I would recommend this game for anyone wanting a casual time killer but come in with low expectations. It's not a revolutionary game but what it does it does it well.

author: {'steamid': '76561198156058850', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 467, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 467, 'last_played': 1494498613}
review:
TurnOn Ã¨ un'avvetura platform nel quale dovrete guidare una "sfera energetica aliena" per riportare l'ordine ad Electrocity.

La maggior parte dei livelli sono pura esplorazione, sottoforma di platform. Nonostante sembri un'accostamento particolare, i due generi sono fusi alla perfezione.
In questi livelli avrete diversi obiettivi, fermare rivolte, salvare persone... sempre saltando da un filo della corrente all'altro, attivando generatori, lampioni, insegne.
Tutto questo vi porta attraverso l'avventura di TurnOn (la sfera di energia), il cui obiettivo principale Ã¨ quello di tornare a casa, sul suo pianeta.

Oltre ai livelli di esplorazione ci sono alcuni "intermezzi" musicali che trasformano il gioco in un "runner ritmico" nel quale dovrete solamente saltare o scendere dalle linee per arrivare alla fine del livello.

Inoltre ci sono due o tre "livelli boss" in cui dovrete, sempre con la stessa meccanica dei fili di corrente, sconfiggere certi nemici, colpendoli nei punti indicati mentre saltate di qua e di lÃ .

[spoiler]L'avventura termina dopo aver riportato l'elettricitÃ  ovunque. Fatto ciÃ², lo scienziato coprotagonista, vi porterÃ  all'ultimo livello, che in realtÃ  non Ã¨ altro che un "livello bonus" senza particolari difficoltÃ , nel quale finalmente partirete con un'astronave diretta nello spazio.[/spoiler]

Il gioco Ã¨ di buonissima fattura [i](specie se consideriamo che Ã¨ prodotto da un piccolo team indie di quattro persone!)[/i].
I livelli di esplorazione rasentano la perfezione. Bellissimo l'effetto "2D/3D" che crea profonditÃ  nei livelli d'esplorazione (in pratica, potete saltare e scendere su fili che si trovano in basso o in alto, anche se questi sono dal punto di vista del giocatore piÃ¹ vicino o piÃ¹ lontano).

I livelli runner sono un po' rivedibili. A volte le linee non sono cosÃ¬ precise, inoltre non si capisce dove siano i checkpoint, per il resto nessun problema.

Gli ambienti sono fantastici e molto dettagliati e lo si capisce giÃ  dai primi livelli.
La colonna sonora Ã¨ una delle migliori che abbia mai sentito. Non snoia, anzi, Ã¨ godibilissima e azzeccatissima!

Achievement tutti assolutamente fattibili, unico problema, Ã¨ capire a volte dove essi vadano fatti.

Nel complesso l'esperienza di gioco Ã¨ stata fanastica, per cui non posso far altro che consigliarvi assolutamente questo titolo!

author: {'steamid': '76561198006215445', 'num_games_owned': 1807, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 484, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1493938678}
review:
Casual, puzzle-light, exploratory kind of a platformer interspersed with runner-like levels.

Original in its premise and take on established genres with its heart in the right place, which makes it such a positive experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093666838', 'num_games_owned': 560, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 222, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 222, 'last_played': 1491882114}
review:
[h1]As an alien creature, you make your way through a world cloaked in darkness, lighting it up as you go through this incredibly colorful and detailed platformer without platforms.[/h1]

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You play as an alien lifeform that needs to light up a dark town via puzzles. There arenâ€™t any platforms per se, but you do travel through the power lines, transformers, etc. Thereâ€™s a lot of exploration and trinkets to pick up in hidden areas as well. If you land on the ground, you will die and will start at a checkpoint. Losing lives in the middle of a level sends you back to the beginning.

There isnâ€™t any dialogue. Instead, the story is purely visual and everything is told through what you see and what you donâ€™t. The cutscenes resemble a graphic novel and you as the player can put the pieces together as the story unfolds.

The levels vary; some will be on-the-rails and youâ€™ll be required to dodge enemies and obstacles as youâ€™re auto-propelled and then there are the freeroam levels where you can freely move and explore at your leisure.

There are various things to collect ranging from lightning bolts to hidden objects found throughout the level. Collecting enough lightning bolts at the end of the level will grant you a better score. Turning on all the lights and hitting switch boxes are the key to getting a high score. Pay close attention, a lot of the utility poles have lamps that will give you points when you turn them on too.

The puzzles have you figuring out how to turn something on, helping someone get somewhere by lighting their way, or turning on a series of lights for someone that open up a new path for you to explore.

The end of each level has a scorecard and 3 lightbulbs. Light up all three when you get a higher score. The 3 buttons on the bottom are Replay, Map, and Next level. So, if you didnâ€™t get all the bolts or didnâ€™t light up all 3 lightbulbs, you can choose to go back through the level.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
I used an Xbox 360 controller for this, but you can also use a keyboard. Left/Right you can use the left thumbstick, on the keyboard itâ€™s A or D. Jumping up is A or W on the keyboard and jumping Down is B or S on the keyboard. There will be moments where you need to time your jumps just right in order to get to certain areas or reach a secret collectible.

[h1]Graphics/Music[/h1]
The entire story is visual, so the visuals here are fantastic. The story cutscenes are told in sort of a graphic novel style panels. The music is pretty chill and reflect the mood or action in each level. All the sounds fit perfectly and donâ€™t take you away from the experience.

[h1]Overall[/h1]
I highly recommend TurnOn, BUT I would wait until itâ€™s on sale or found in a bundle. At itâ€™s current price of $14.99, thatâ€™s a pretty steep price for about 4-5 hours of gameplay. Personally, I feel that this should be in the ballpark of around $5 for the limited amount of gameplay if you arenâ€™t a completionist.

Overall, the visual story coupled with the intuitive gameplay where the entire level becomes your playing field makes for a very casual game. Having to light up the city becomes fun and a challenge where youâ€™re curious as to what other secrets or lights you can turn on to rack up the highest score. TurnOn by Brainy Studios is in the Steam store, link in the description.

review:
Sobre un control de personaje plano se aplica un escenario poligonal y cuadrangular para establecer una profundidad de campo que pueda desviar y ampliar sus posibilidades jugables hacia la tercera dimensiÃ³n de la plataforma o escenario, con mecÃ¡nica fluida.
La fÃ³rmula es muy singular hacia su presentaciÃ³n artÃ­stica y demuestra ser notoria, no teniendo conflictos en lo que a su base cuadrangular se refiere: admite cualquier cosa que se pueda imaginar dentro de su concepto.

El juego aprovecha bien todo su potencial, distribuyendo casi su completa jugabilidad hacia un atmosfÃ©rico y visual escenario explorativo. Sus plataformas y detalle se funden para potenciar su jugabilidad explorativa que se plantea como un recorrido localizativo. Extremadamente recomendado.

Aparte de esta jugabilidad o niveles muy divertidos nos vamos a encontrar con otro tipo de niveles en mucha menos cantidad que serÃ¡n de reflejos, en donde la jugabilidad cambiarÃ¡ radicalmente a esquivar obstÃ¡culos en un pista de caminos paralelos con un scroll rapidÃ­simo que puede complicarnos el terminar el juego.

author: {'steamid': '76561198051824204', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1488072077}
review:
Found this game mostly relaxing platformer, not overly difficult and save/checkpoints are reasonably spaced. But, the levels racing against the clock/music based levels can get tedious/fustrating. 

Great music tracks, really wish you could almost own the soundtrack separately 

Bought on special

author: {'steamid': '76561198163622312', 'num_games_owned': 4652, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 266, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 266, 'last_played': 1487886678}
review:
The game caught my attention at launch. It turns out that the theme, the design, and the music (especially the music!) are all pretty good. The controls are sometimes sloppy, making some levels very hard to beat (Looking at you! You running-on-cable levels!!!)

Overall it's a good platformer to enjoy some peaceful time and throw your controller/smash your keyboards with frustration. ;)  7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561197963897896', 'num_games_owned': 963, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 498, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 498, 'last_played': 1487804642}
review:
My first impression of this game was good.  It has a nice art style and the idea of repowering the city by jumping from electrical platform to electrical platform and reaching collectibles and different goals seemed cool to me.  Especially the way the story is told appeals to me.  In one level you're powering homes to get the lights on in order to scare away burglars attempting to get inside.  In another level, you're bringing a man and a woman together for their date by turning on traffic lights to make it safe to cross streets, getting a water pump running to spray malicious thugs, and so on.  In this way, the game is great.  The leisurely way you roam the levels and interact with things to see the effect you have on them and watch a small story unfold - it's relaxing and fun.

And then there's the reason I give this game a thumbs down.  There are about 6 levels that are "runner" levels.  You are automatically moving forward along power lines and all you can do is jump up or down them.  These levels can be immensely frustrating depending on how you play them.  I, for instance, really want to get everything and achieve a high score.  To do that, you need to get almost every collectible in the stage.  Make mistakes, and you get to start the level over - the checkpoints are few and far between.  Imagine playing DDR and you make three mistakes and it automatically starts you off at the beginning of the song again.  The music in this game is nice, but you start to hate it when you hear it over and over again fifty times.  

Of course, you don't have to try to collect everything and get a high score.  You can just run through these levels casually.  However, if you're doing that, they're too easy and there's not much to do.  You press W a few times, you press S a few times and you're done.  Unlike the normal levels, there's no story, no exploration in these levels.  If you're not trying to collect everything, these levels serve no purpose.  And if you are collecting everything, they're pure frustration.  The camera is way too zoomed in, you can't see far enough ahead of you and often cannot react to things immediately enough to accomplish anything.  I don't feel the controls are as responsive as I'd like, either, though this may just be my perception - I press W at times and it doesn't jump.  The level design of these runner levels have caused the community as a whole to just exploit them.  If you've reached a checkpoint, your collectibles are saved if you die from falling, so you keep dying on purpose over and over again to collect as many as you can manage before completing the level.  This just proves bad level design.  I feel they were only added to give the game a false sense of challenge.  They don't seem to fit the overall mood of the rest of the game - one of exploration and interaction within a beautiful world.

With the runner levels, I must give this game a thumbs down.  They are either too hard or too easy, depending on your playstyle, and simply don't fit with the rest of the narrative or gameplay.  Otherwise, this game would get a thumbs up.  Regardless, it's a worthy game to play casually if you can get it really cheap on sale.  The game takes less than 5 hours to complete.

author: {'steamid': '76561197983066158', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 806, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 800, 'last_played': 1490874060}
review: TurnOn is een plezierige en hartverwarmend spelletje. Met elektrische draden in plaats van platforms, biedt gameplay die fris aanvoelt, piquing uw interesse bij elke beurt met wat nieuw avontuur of obstakel u de volgende keer mee te maken krijgt.

author: {'steamid': '76561198095868469', 'num_games_owned': 471, 'num_reviews': 71, 'playtime_forever': 774, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1594145015}
review:
Okay, 3 years after first review, after finally beating game, I'll switch it from NO to YES.
Game looks really cute and rather promising. Mostly it's relaxing puzzle platformer. Calm, enjoyable, beautiful. 
But several runner levels are total disaster. They have no sense and are absolutely opposite to whole game - too fast, too hard, too repetitive. There are too less checkpoints and lives in them, so be prepared to hate and repeat them again and again and again... 
And after finally beating any runner - you''ll be rewarded with few more relaxing levels. And then runner again...
Totally game isn't bad. It could be much better without runner levels. But still it is rather good, unusual and enjoyable.

author: {'steamid': '76561198018061433', 'num_games_owned': 1510, 'num_reviews': 1588, 'playtime_forever': 279, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 279, 'last_played': 1485997252}
review:
Wir steuern lebendiger, elektrischer Funke und mÃ¼ssen eine ganze Stadt und ihre Bereiche wieder mit Strom versorgen. WunderschÃ¶ne Spielwelt und ein weltklasse Soundtrack lassen einen das ganze gerne machen. Da es immer um das selbe geht ist es ein Gelegenheitsspiel, da auch die Story simple und doch niedlich ist. Zwischendurch gibt es noch Levels wo Reflexe gefragt sind, da es dort nur ums Ã¼berleben geht. Spielzeit : 3-4 Stunden, wenn man fast alles einsammelt. Es ist auch mÃ¶glich nur die Ziele abzuarbeiten und durch die Level zu rennen. Dann sind es vielleicht nur 2-3 Stunden. Wodurch man TurnOn im Angebot unter 10â‚¬ kaufen sollte.


+ Soundtrack
+ Grafik
+ Steuerung (nur WASD oder mit einem Controller)
+ viel zum einsammeln
+ einfach nur symphatisch 
+ Trotz "immer das selbe tun", kam bei mir keine Langeweile auf, wie bei vielen anderen Gelegenheitsspielen. Da jedes Level anders aufgebaut ist.

author: {'steamid': '76561198034072369', 'num_games_owned': 13581, 'num_reviews': 76, 'playtime_forever': 217, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 217, 'last_played': 1484963912}
review:
[h1] TurnOn [/h1]

DISCLAIMER: I received this product for no cost for the purpose of reviewing. However, this does not affect my views and opinions of the game.

TurnOn is a colourful little side-scrolling puzzle platformer where you play as some sort of alien ball of electricity. Your job is to return light to a city that has plunged into darkness by repairing wires, turning on switches and completing circuits that restore electricity to the town. You work along side a scientist who sort of moves along each level with you. Together you overcome obstacles and puzzles in order to save the city from it's blackout. 

--------

[b] Graphics: 7 / 10 [/b]

The graphic assets of the game are quite lovely. Each stage is presented differently with some great animation and lighting effects. It's a very colourful game despite the basis of the game being about lighting up a darkened area. The art-style is very cartoon-y but works well with the theme of the game. The game runs fine on any low to mid-tier setup.

--------

[b] Sound: 7 / 10 [/b]

The soundtrack of the game is also very well done. The game's music sets a nice tone for each of it's stages while at the same time following the game's motif. The other sound assets of the game are pretty standard, though they do get the job done. 

--------

[b] Mechanics: 6 / 10 [/b]

The game has very solid mechanics, and plays how a puzzle platformer is expected too. You move your character around with the WASD keys and can jump using the space bar. Your goal is to traverse through the wires, hitting switches to turn the power back on, and return electricity to certain areas.

There will be puzzles in your way such as; which power boxes to activate and in which order, which wires to jump and travel on or which direction to move in. It is not very difficult, although the obstacles do become progressively more challenging as you continue to play. 

You more or less only die in the game if you make a blind jump off screen into the wrong area, which can be a problem as there are certain points within the game where you do need to make blind jumps. 

--------

[b] Final Personal Remarks: [/b] 

The game is really cute and colourful. It's something I can see people playing when they want to take a break from playing more intense games. It's not incredibly difficult either. It's more of a highly stylized maze. You can see where you need to go during each stage, and if you get stuck, a bit of trial and error will usually overcome the challenge. I do think the game is enjoyable, and there might be some more value to the game for those who enjoy speed running. 

Thanks to the devs for giving me the opportunity to review the game, as well as anyone who took this review into consideration, I hope it helped.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971456463', 'num_games_owned': 2257, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 564, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 564, 'last_played': 1485360749}

author: {'steamid': '76561198136399370', 'num_games_owned': 641, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 678, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 448, 'last_played': 1528298267}
review:
Â¿Buscas un juego medianamente corto? Â¿Indie? Â¿Con una buena banda sonora (en mi opiniÃ³n)? Â¿Buscas un juego de plataformas? Â¿Te gustan los personajes medianamente entraÃ±ables? De eso trata TurnOn.
 
Un juego indie de plataformas con una buena banda sonora. Eres un alien electricidad y tienes que ir activando cosas pasando por distintas plataformas. A veces debes pensar de otro modo para avanzar y hay algunas cosas algo "injustas" pero en general me ha encantado.

Mono y divertido.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027343237', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1481951155}
review:
I bought this game at 70% off for $4.49 USD. At that price, it is perhaps barely worth it.

This game tries to do too many things, and is consequently mediocre at everything it does. It's mostly a platformer with the twist that rather than a person jumping from platform to platform, you are a living electricity... thing... jumping from wire to wire. This is a good concept, poorly executed.

Rather than provide the player with a consistent view of the world with which they interact, the game instead uses perspective to decide where you will land from any given jump. So you can jump from foreground to background, so long as the wires line up right from player perspective.
Unfortunately, the player has no control over the camera, which is often oriented to funnel you through the path the designers laid out for you. What's more, the designers evidently aren't very experienced. Several times, the only way to proceed was to take a leap of faith, on the assumption that there would be a wire to catch me offscreen.

Often, though, the game will switch over to a sort of rhythm game wannabe, where you are moving forward, only able to jump up or down between wires. These segments are possibly the worst part of the game. They seem placed at "climactic" moments in the story structure (in so far as this game has a story).
Yet if you fall off the wires, you're placed back at the last checkpoint, which in these segments are unmarked and uncommon. The song also resets to match where in the level you were sent back to. It's not even a seamless transition. It's very abrupt, yet not fast.
Oh, and the speed at which you're moving can change without warning.

Most levels involve reaching the transformer at the end, with various collectibles and fuseboxes on the way. The fuseboxes, when touched, will activate something in the world, such as neon lights or a winch. Some levels require you to solve a "puzzle" in the world, such as guiding a couple in love to each other. In practice, this is just another collectible with cutscenes attached. Which wouldn't be a bad thing, but the art in the game is, again, mediocre.

The "art" in the game consists of the 3D environments which contain the wires you move through, and 2D drawn comic-style "storytelling" cutscenes. You would think the art in the cutscenes would be of better quality, but it's awful. And the 3D art is merely passable.

I haven't said all I can about this game. But by now I think you get the gist of it. My recommendation, if you're going to buy this game, is wait until it's on sale. like, 60% off at least. It's nowhere near worth $15.

author: {'steamid': '76561198072401397', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 268, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 268, 'last_played': 1481931568}
review:
1 Did the developer screw Windows Phone users?
2 Yes! Is balance of difficulty plain wierd in some levels? Sure.
3 Is the game short? Mhm....

But in the end, the atmosphere and story telling is simple and perfect with a straightforward soundtrack. This is one of thouse games that stands out on its own uniqueness and merits even if it have faults. Its not about the difficulty in the puzzles, its about exploring gorgeous graphical settings and turning on light bubs with easy story telling. Its a kids game in most perspective, but like thouse good animated movies from Pixar that we adults still love to watch. So do you like cozy atmosphere, a nice soundstrack and a rather easy straightforward entertaning peace of art? Go ahead and buy it.

review: I really want to like this game. The exploring is really fun. But during the timed levels there just are not enough save points. I'm not good at precision platforming. author: {'steamid': '76561198018686466', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 166, 'playtime_forever': 9, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1470725946}
review:
Unplayable on Windows 10 with Xbox controller. The controls constantly get stuck to the left which causes you to die almost every minute. At first I was an idiot and thought that was the intended gameplay, and disliked it for a whole other reason - but then finally found someone else mention this being a bug. The graphics look amazing but from what I played (ignoring my hanicap) it seemed a bit bland.

TLDR; Be careful before buying if on Windows 10 with Xbox controller.

author: {'steamid': '76561198080482559', 'num_games_owned': 140, 'num_reviews': 41, 'playtime_forever': 1050, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 159, 'last_played': 1516038200}
review:
For an hour or so I was going to give this game my huge 'thumb up'... but now I'm not so sure. Here's why. 

I though it was going to be a relaxing and casual exploration\puzzle platformer...which it is. [i]Mostly[/i]. 

Several levels had been designed to add some kind of 'challange', but they only add frustration instead. 'Boss fight'  with the copter had been the worst so far, but those few 'runner' levels I've seen also leave much to be desired. I suppose they were meant to mimic a rhythm-based gameplay, where following the music is a right way to jump through all the gaps, traps and such...but the thing is - jump\air control is not too strong in this one. It's mediocre (to say the least), which is not a death-crime for a nicely drawn casual family-friendly platformer, really...if not for those 'annoying.... oh, I mean 'challenging' levels.

Do I recommend the game? May be. Especially with a good discount. Just have in mind, that it's not that 'casual' and 'relaxing' as it seems to be.  Nice art, good music, interesting 'character' (if that's the word for a glowing electric bubble). but those levels? Meh..

author: {'steamid': '76561198004242986', 'num_games_owned': 1612, 'num_reviews': 24, 'playtime_forever': 238, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 238, 'last_played': 1476334600}
review:
I wanted to like this game. A lot. I loved the art style a lot. The animations had a little bit of jank to them, but that just added to the charm for me. 

The gameplay held me back though. Making a fun platformer is about good level design, good camera control and the controls feeling right. TurnOn doesn't exceed at any of these and it ends up making the entire experience worse off for it. 

TurnOn has mostly okay level design except for a few areas where you have to do blind faith jumps because the only way to progress is to jump to an offscreen rope. The game often has no indicator of these so enjoy sometimes blindly jumping to your death. The camera control is bad... or rather there is no camera control. The camera is hard locked to your character so you can't just test to see if it's a blind faith jump and airstrafe back. Despite there being no punishment for jumping to your death, this does make this part of the game incredibly tedious, especially for the 4-5 second respawn animation and it teleporting you back to the last checkpoint. The gameplay works on a 2d plane, however there can be multiple 2d planes for you to jump between in a single level. This can work in the game and sometimes it's pretty novel, but for the most part you'll probably find it incredibly annoying. The camera will flick up and the scenery will move in an attempt to get you to hook onto the scene behind -- even if it isn't possible for you to successfully make the jump. This will make jumping for the collectibles annoying, but it will also make you try and jump up to an area that may not be accessible at all. 

As a causal platformer, these issues would be annoying, but just an annoyance on an otherwise enjoyable game, right? Well that's until you play the annoying auto run levels. These appear to be synced up to the music, but it's done very poorly. Instead enjoy a lot of trial and error and hearing the same part of the song as you unsuccessfully try and make your way through. At first it's a neat gimmick, but the game continues to throw them at you. 

Ugh. I really don't want to rate this game down. I don't feel good about it, but I cannot recommend this in good earnest. What a shame.

author: {'steamid': '76561198053990010', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 260, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 260, 'last_played': 1475455030}
review:
Overall, I enjoyed this game a lot.  The music was really nice (I hope they'll put out a soundtrack for purchase) and the concept was fun.  Some jumps did not work quite like I expected them to, and your character's sprite can be very obviously 2D at times but I enjoyed the look and feel of the game.  The exploration levels were definitely my favorites, though since I played the first 2/3 of the game three months ago I can't pick the best one.

The forced scrolling levels are frustrating as there seems to be one checkpoint in those at best, far into the level, and if you die due to too many hits (instead of just falling off the course) you go all the way back to the start instead of the checkpoint.  I always seemed to die just when the music was really kicking in...   Also, the second-to-last level is really luck-based to finish.  Hop around like mad and hope!

I played on a 360 controller and that worked well, not sure how their other schemes work out.  If you aren't sure about the two gameplay styles (and the forced scrolling sections seem more frequent the further you get in the game) watch the second video (the one in the middle), it shows both kind of levels and gives a good idea of how it feels.

$15 may be a bit high, but I caught it on sale.  Also, there are occasional bugs (I hit one on the Ferris Wheel level) where a level just won't complete.  Luckily (?) restarting the level worked out.  I still think it was a fun game, but you should know that it's not perfect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198159585437', 'num_games_owned': 381, 'num_reviews': 63, 'playtime_forever': 280, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 225, 'last_played': 1475528525}
review:
This is an absolutely beautiful game. The graphics are charming, the background characters slapstick (they remind me a bit of the incidental characters in Splosion Man) and the music just fits it so well; I often turn in-game music off while I listen to my own music but this gets my full attention.

It's quite a unique play mechanism too. An absolute joy to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019430260', 'num_games_owned': 545, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 510, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 484, 'last_played': 1475336217}
review:
â€œTurnOnâ€ is an interesting platformer involving slack electrical wires and slightly leaning electric poles. The product of a four-man team, Russian-based Brainy Studios, â€œTurnOnâ€ features an electrical alien creature of the same name. Players control this creature as they journey to bring power back to a blackout city.

Other than having wires as platforms instead of rigid, straight planes, the gameâ€™s penchant for relaxing players lies behind its lack of dialogue and soothing soundtrack. Sound effects are limited, but for a good cause - they keep the experience free of distractions as much as possible. They easily blend in with the background, save for a few manufactured shrieks and grunts for the humans. Cutscenes are presented in a comic-book style, allowing for an easy-in-easy-out process while saving space in order to show the most number of panels.

The soundtrack, on the other hand, range from jazz-like tracks to easy-listen instrumentals. They match each stage perfectly - peaceful stages are accompanied by the soft, hushed tracks, while the slightly more stressful stages are more upbeat. Even the most touching cutscenes elicit just the right amount of emotion.

As for the gameplay itself, â€œTurnOnâ€ boasts two kinds of platforming: free roam and autoscroller. Free roam stages usually require the player to fulfill some kind of small mission, ranging from helping light up the environment for a date to saving kids from a horribly failing ferris wheel. Collectibles come in the form of blue bolts and are half the requirement for getting a perfect rating for the stage. The other half involves giving power to lamps and air conditioning units strewn around the map. These two tasks provide points, which are tallied at the end of each stage and are assigned a one, two, or three light bulb rating.

One of the more interesting concepts of the free roam stages is the way the focus shifts from foreground to background as needed. Seemingly higher and unreachable wires are usually reached by a slight leap of faith and a sudden shift of focus planes. Itâ€™s a little scary at times, especially when making a significant jump from a high plane to low plane. Itâ€™s also slightly startling at the beginning, but throughout the game it becomes second nature.

The other kind of stages come in the form of autoscrolling levels. Given its nature, the path is more straightforward and there are only a set number of platforms to worry about. The goal is the same: collect all blue bolts and reach the end of the stage.

The main difference lies in the sudden difficulty spike. It is during these stages that players must summon some quick reactions in order to quickly change platforms. The speed is never the same - they slow down and speed up according to the accompanying soundtrack. Donâ€™t be fooled, however. Even though the jumps seem like they are in tune with the soundtrackâ€™s rhythm, they quickly go out of sync with the music. This makes for an awkward transition from enjoying the track to quickly ignoring it in order to keep going.

----------------------

Read the full review at http://playertheory.com/review/turnon

author: {'steamid': '76561198044602606', 'num_games_owned': 7495, 'num_reviews': 544, 'playtime_forever': 322, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 322, 'last_played': 1471232710}
review:
[h1]TurnOn: A Charmingly Electric Journey[/h1]


TurnOn is a charming platformer/runner where you play an alien ball of electricity who has crash landed in a city causing a blackout, and must then restore both the power and help the citizens out in the process. This was a mostly enjoyable experience that took me  4.8 hours to complete. There were a few parts of the game where I got stuck for a little while, which extended my time a bit. A player with solid platformer and runner skills could probably play through this in about 3 hours if they wanted.



[h1]Story[/h1]


The story in TurnOn is presented without any captions or voice work. It is a strictly visual experience from this standpoint. That said, it does in fact carry itself reasonably well in the story department. Basically, this is the tale of an alien who crash lands in a city (and fortunately in a scientists laboratory) causing a city wide blackout. The alien, who is represented as a ball of electricity, and who can only travel via electrical currents (such as power lines and such), and the scientist together attempt to restore power to the city before the people in the city destroy it via looting and other crime, accidents, and what have you. You, the alien, will also try to help people along the way, from helping out a couple on a romantic date to making it possible for a kid to finish his round of mini golf (and other stuff as well). Certainly the story in TurnOn is no magnum opus, but it serves well within the context of this platformer.


I give the story a 7 out of 10


[h1]Gameplay[/h1]



The gameplay in both a platformer and a runner is of paramount importance. Brainy Studios did a very nice job of creating a seamless experience in this regard. The controls in TurnOn were tight using a gamepad (I didnt try keyboard and mouse, so I have no opinion ion that manner of play for this game). I experienced zero crashes or stuttering. There is one amusing bug that will show up however. You can sometimes end up travelling along invisible power lines. This happened probably 8-10 times in my playthrough. Each time, this bug worked to my advantage as it made jumps between power lines a bit easier.

So, the actual gameplay itself:

The platforming was fairly basic overall. As mentioned before, in TurnOn, you travel via power lines and electrical currents. These are presented in a number of ways, from straight lines to mazing paths, with shifts in elevation, and moving platforms (such as window washing lifts, the scientists vehicle, forklifts, etcâ€¦). There will also be bridges that you need to power up to unlock, doorways that need to be unlocked, street lights that need to be turned on, and so on. Along the way, you collect currents of electricity (which basically take the place of the more familiar coins in platformers) which impact your ranking on each level and are attached to certain achievements. There are also red charges of electricity which damage you and green charges which heal that damage and basically give you up to 3 health points. If you run out of green energy, you will have to completely restart the level you are on.
The running sections I personally found to be a bit frustrating. Not because they werent done well. They were. I simply am not so good at that style of gameplay. However, despite my deficiency in this regard, I was still able to complete each level with some trial and error. You are still traveling across electrical lines, and so the presentation for the runner levels is basically like sheet music, with a few different levels and breaks on various ones causing you to have to stay on top of your game and change lines frequently. The pacing is tied to the music in the game, so the faster the tempo, the faster you are running.


You will also encounter enemies on a few levels in TurnOn, which are variations on red energy. They are fairly easy to avoid overall, but you will still die plenty of times on a few of those levels. There is also what is essentially a timed level towards the end. This was the level I had the most problems with overall. Again, it was done well, but I still died a lot trying to figure out and remember the patterns as I ascended a building trying to stay ahead of a line of red energy that inexorably advanced upon my little electrical alien.

The gameplay in TurnOn deserves an 8 out of 10.

 

[h1]Graphics[/h1]


The graphics in TurnOn were are presented in comic book fashion. The intros for each section are actual comic book frames which let you know what challenges you will face in the level to a certain extent and what your overall goals are. The actual game graphics are an extension of this comic book approach. They were especially well done in my opinion and the highlight of TurnOn for me. This was simply put a beautiful and lovingly crafted game from a graphics standpoint.

I think this game deserves a 9 out of 10 for this category. The graphics in TurnOn were almost done to perfection


[h1]Sound[/h1]


I have mixed feelings towards the audio in TurnOn. The music was the sort of stuff you would expect to hear in inspirational videos and commercials. Sort of uplifting, but also a bit sterile. The rest of the audio was simply sounds of electrical discharge, muttering speech done intentionally to further the voiceless story telling, and other ambient noises appropriate to the various backdrops. This was the low point of the game from my perspective

6 out of 10


[h1]Verdict[/h1]


Taken as a whole, TurnOn was a pleasant gaming experience. The setting and main character were charming. I was also impressed by the fact that this game was crafted by a four person team.

[h1]7.5 aliens traversing the electrical wire ways of our neon world charming the socks off of those they encounter within. Out of 10.[/h1]

https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32549618/[/code]

author: {'steamid': '76561198003030375', 'num_games_owned': 3129, 'num_reviews': 773, 'playtime_forever': 270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 270, 'last_played': 1469543790}
review:
TurnOn:
~~~~~~

This is incredible and you are not going believe it - Electro City power station has suffered a slight malfunction, causing the entire city to be blacked-out! Electro City without electricity â€“ unbelievable! Thankfully, Professor Brain was on duty when the event occurred, and by fluke he found a Spark. Not the kind of light-bulb spark you get when you have a great idea,  but â€œSparkâ€, a courageous alien with plenty of zap who will help our professor to restore electricity to the city!

TurnOn is a platformer/adventure game where you play â€œSpark,â€ an alien who looks like an electric blue ball. The aim of the game is to travel throughout the city and restore power to houses and re-activate generators so the citizens can go about their lives as usual. 

â€œSparkâ€ will travel the city jumping from wire to wire to turn on light poles, activate generators, restore electricity to houses and public places.  On the wires, you will notice electric icons. The blue ones are collectables and each time you pick one up, it will give you a point. You will need to accumulate as many as possible to successfully turn on three lights at the end of the level. If you go over the red electric icons, you will lose one of the three green electric icons which represent â€œSparkâ€™sâ€ lives. If you lose all of these, you will restart the level from scratch. The other way to die is if you miscalculate a jump and fall down on the concrete. However, you will not lose any points and you will restart from your last checkpoint, which is the last large generator you activated. This type of level is more or less like a typical platformer. The other type of level is the one where you move from one part of the city to another. Very similar, but it is faster and reminds me of a runner genre of game.  It will become harder when you will have to avoid obstacles and enemies within the levels.
 
If you enjoy collecting in-game achievements, TurnOn has plenty of them and they are quiet easy to gain.   
The 2.5D artwork is really good and I enjoyed the soundtrack. In terms of the controls, you can play with your mouse and keyboard, or with a gamepad.

Positives:
~~~~~~~ 

-	Good artwork
-	Two types of levels
-	Controls are responsive
-	Good soundtrack
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~  
-	You might get frustrated in the runner levels.

Turn On the light of Electro city is a well-designed game and should see the light in your game library!

7/10

Key provided by developer/publisher for review purposes. Any opinions expressed are entirely my own!
